corrections.explanation: This sentence uses "will" because it's referring to future events. It is inappropriate to use the past tense "caused" for events that have not occurred or might not occur, so it should be changed to "cause." (This is an especially tricky example because the future tense "will" is followed directly by "if not already," which references a potential past event. It should be phrased "This will cause problems in the future, if it has not already, as there is very limited space for us.")
The subject of the verb is "space," which is singular, so for subject-verb agreement, it should be changed to "is."

Space can be treated as either countable or uncountable. As a countable noun, it means area delineated for a specific purpose and it can be made plural. As an uncountable noun, which cannot be made plural, it means an amount of area that is unoccupied. This is the sense of meaning used when talking about "limited space," so it cannot be made plural.

incorrect sentence: This will , if not already , caused problems as there are very limited spaces for us .
correct sentence: This will , if not already , cause problems as there is very limited space for us .

corrections.explanation: This sentence is using the passive modal, which requires a form of the verb "to be" and the past participle of a verb. In this construction, the verb form must always be the past participle, so "obtain" should be changed to "obtained."

The preposition "in" means inside of or surrounded by, so "the problems in lands that are inhospitable" means problems that exist in inhospitable lands. The preposition "of" indicates ownership, association, or the nature of something, so "the problem of lands that are inhospitable" means that the nature of the problem is that the lands are inhospitable. That is the intended meaning here, so "in" should be changed to "of."
The "are" in the phrase "lands that are inhospitable" is necessary because a form of the verb "to be" is needed to link the noun "lands" with the adjective "inhospitable."
This is a spelling error. The word "desserts" refers to sweets, and "deserts" refers to barren areas of landscape.

incorrect sentence: The solution can be obtain by using technology to achieve a better usage of space that we have and resolve the problems in lands that inhospitable such as desserts and swamps .
correct sentence: The solution can be obtained by using technology to achieve a better usage of space that we have and resolve the problems of lands that are inhospitable such as deserts and swamps .

corrections.explanation: The infinitive verb "to get" is missing. "Managing a place to live" means taking care of a residential property, while "managing to get a place to live" means securing housing. This sentence is talking about the problems of overpopulation, so the meaning of securing housing is appropriate, and the infinitive should be added.
Countries have more than one citizen, so the plural "citizens" should be used here instead of the singular "citizen."

incorrect sentence: Some countries are having difficulties in managing a place to live for their citizen as they tend to get overpopulated .
correct sentence: Some countries are having difficulties in managing to get a place to live for their citizens as they tend to get overpopulated .

corrections.explanation: The present perfect tense is used to describe events that occurred in the past but continue into or affect the present. It requires a form of the auxiliary verb "to have" plus the past participle of a verb. The phrase "this has caused problems" conveys that past overpopulation has already caused problems (the formation and growth of slums) that still persist today.
The sentence lists two problems, the formation of slums and the growth of slums. Therefore, the plural should be used.

"Appearance" refers to either the way a person/thing looks or the act of performing/participating in a public event. The noun "appearance" cannot be used to refer to the process of slums appearing in a city, so it should be changed to "formation and growth."
The subject of this verb is "slums," which is plural, so the verb "are" should be used for subject-verb agreement.
I don't think this correction is strictly necessary. It is grammatically correct and not inaccurate to say that slums "are not safe due to their unhealthy environment."

The determiner "their" is used to convey the relationship between the "slums" and the "unhealthy environment." The environment is regarded as an aspect or characteristic of the slum, and this relationship is expressed using possessiveness. The characteristic of being unsafe belongs to the slum, so the possessive determiner "their" is used to convey this ownership.

incorrect sentence: This caused problem like the appearance of slums which most of the time is not safe due to the unhealthy environment .
correct sentence: This has caused problems like the formation and growth of slums which most of the time are not safe to live in due to their unhealthy environment .

corrections.explanation: The preposition "of" indicates the source of something or a relationship of ownership, so the phrase "the demands of space" means demands that are coming from space or that belong to space, which is not logical. The preposition "for" can mean in order to get something, so "the demands for space" means that someone is demanding space. To convey this meaning, "of" should be changed to "for."

"Land" is a general concept that should be familiar to the reader, so it does not take the definite article "the" when used in a general sense. "The" is used with land only when drawing a distinction or a comparison between different areas of land, and not in a general statement like this.

The pronoun "it" is used instead of "land" but it can easily be mistaken to be referring to "building" instead. It should be changed to make the meaning clearer. Also, the phrase "the same area of land" in particular emphasizes the author's point about achieving better usage of land, as the same land can now accommodate more people.
Either "more people" or "a greater number of people" would be acceptable, but they cannot be mixed.
The meaning "with the same (space)" is already conveyed by the edit "the same area of land," so it is redundant to restate it.

incorrect sentence: The only way to satisfy the increasing demands of space is by achieving a better usage of the land like designing taller building so it can accommodate more number of people with the same spaces .
correct sentence: The only way to satisfy the increasing demands for space is by achieving a better usage of land like designing taller building so the same area of land can accommodate a greater number of people .

corrections.explanation: The verb "create" means to bring something into existence, so "to create a material" means to develop a material that does not exist yet. The intended meaning of this sentence is not to develop a new material but to construct buildings with a better material, so the verb "use" should be used instead.

The indefinite article "a" refers to one thing, so the phrase "create a better material" to create one material, but this sentence is about material in general. In this case, it is common to say "create better material," in which "material" is an uncountable noun meaning matter from which something is made, or "create better materials," in which "materials" can refer to various building materials.

"Building" is a general concept that should be familiar to the reader, so it does not take the definite article "the" when referred to in a general sense. "The" is used with "buildings" in order to draw a distinction or a comparison between different buildings, but not in a general statement like this.

"Despite" means in spite of or not being affected by something. "During" means throughout the duration of an event. This sentence isn't referring to materials that can support a building in spite of the occurrence of disasters, but materials that allow a building to withstand disasters by providing support throughout the duration of a disaster. Therefore, "during" should be used instead.

When referencing natural disasters in general, the plural "disasters" should be used because it is a category that refers to earthquakes, typhoons, and multiple other things. The singular "disaster" is used to refer to an individual disaster, with "a disaster" meaning any disaster and "the disaster" meaning one specific disaster.

incorrect sentence: It is also important to create a better material that can support the buildings despite any natural disaster like earthquakes .
correct sentence: It is also important to use better material that can support buildings during any natural disasters like earthquakes .

corrections.explanation: A comma is needed between "Japan" and "where" to mark the start of a non-essential clause. A non-essential clause is part of a sentence that can be removed without destroying the meaning of the sentence. It provides information about the essential clause. The phrase "A good example is Japan" is a complete sentence on its own, and the non-essential clause is "where there are... there." The comma shows where the clause begins, clarifying the meaning of the sentence.
The phrase "there" already implies a location, so it does not use a preposition. Also, the phrase "in there" refers to the inside of a tangible object, not a geographical location.

incorrect sentence: A good example is Japan where there are a lot of tall condominiums despite the large number of earthquakes happening in there .
correct sentence: A good example is Japan , where there are a lot of tall condominiums despite the large number of earthquakes happening there .

corrections.explanation: In most contexts, the noun "land" is used as a collective noun, so "land" is both the singular and the plural.
The noun "sanitation" is uncountable because it refers to a process. It does not take the indefinite article "a" because it is uncountable and intangible.

If a statement is referring to future events, it is inappropriate to use the present tense, which refers to the current state of affairs. To talk about the future, use the future tense, which consists of "will" plus the bare infinitive.
This is a spelling error. A "heath" is a kind of plant or a marshland, while "health" refers to a state of wellbeing without illness or injury.

incorrect sentence: Besides a better usage of lands , a better sanitation is also needed because a huge number of people need a clean environment to maintain their heath .
correct sentence: Besides a better usage of land , better sanitation is also needed because a huge number of people will need a clean environment to maintain their health .

corrections.error: reforms the land to make it livable
corrections.correct: restore the land to a livable state
corrections.explanation: The word "reform" is used for man-made things and not for nature. "Restore," meaning to return to a previous state, is a better choice, especially given the context of needing better sanitation. "To make it livable" implies that the land was not livable in the past, while "restore to a livable state" implies that the conditions that currently make the land unlivable, or the unsanitary state, can be addressed, allowing the land to return to its original, livable state.

The verb "help" can be either transitive or intransitive, and when used as intransitive, it doesn't require an object. Without the pronoun "it," the phrase "technology can help" means that technology can contribute or make things easier.

The noun "trouble" means problems that the land has, and it has a negative connotation. "Quality" means attributes or characteristics, and it has a neutral connotation. "Quality" expresses that technology can be applied as appropriate for the characteristics of the land, rather than solely to address problems.

incorrect sentence: Countries with a lot of inhospitable space need not only to achieve a better space usage , but also to reforms the land to make it livable and technology can help it in a number of ways depending on the trouble the lands have .
correct sentence: Countries with a lot of inhospitable space need not only to achieve a better space usage , but also to restore the land to a livable state and technology can help in a number of ways depending on the quality of the land .

corrections.explanation: This is a spelling error. The word "desserts" refers to sweets, and "deserts" refers to barren areas of landscape.
The verb "terraform" means to transform a landscape so as to resemble the Earth, so it is rarely used for earth environments, only other planets.
This is part of a verb phrase with the auxiliary verb "can," which requires the bare infinitive and not the gerund. Therefore, the gerund "using" should be changed to "use."

incorrect sentence: For example , countries with a lot of deserts can terraform their desert to increase their habitable land and using irrigation to provide clean water to the desert .
correct sentence: For example , countries with a lot of desert can transform their desert to increase their habitable land and use irrigation to provide clean water to the desert .

corrections.explanation: I don't agree with this correction. In written English, it is incorrect to start a sentence with "but." The meaning is also clearer as one sentence with the conjunction "but," as in "...the country (has) almost no natural water, but it uses irrigation..."

I don't agree with this correction. First, the capitalized "But" is only used at the start of a sentence, but the meaning is clearer as one sentence. Therefore, I would keep the structure as is, without capitalizing the conjunction. Second, I think either "and" or "but" can be used here depending on the nuance. "And" is used to connect similar concepts or add more information, while "but" is used to connect concepts that are different or that contradict expectations. This correction is for style or meaning, not grammar.
This pronoun needs to refer to Dubai, a country. Countries use the pronoun "it" instead of "they."
The subject is "it," which is singular, so the verb should be changed to "uses" for subject-verb agreement.

incorrect sentence: Dubai will be a good example for this as previously the country got almost no natural water and they use irrigation to bring natural water to the country .
correct sentence: Dubai will be a good example for this as previously the country got almost no natural water . But it uses irrigation to bring natural water to the country .

corrections.explanation: The word "whose" refers to people, not to countries. For countries, use "where" or "which."

"His" is the singular male possessive pronoun, so it is used to indicate ownership by a single male person. The subject is the Netherlands, and gendered pronouns are not used for countries. Also, the possessive aspect is already conveyed by the edit "whose," so it would be redundant to use another possessive. Therefore the definite article "the" should be used instead.
In most contexts, the noun "land" is used as a collective noun, so "land" is both the singular and the plural.

The indefinite article "a" refers to one thing, so the phrase "most of the land is a swamp" means that there is one swamp that covers most of the Netherlands. In reality, most of the land is swampland but the country is not a single swamp, so "a" should be removed.

To make a new sentence, replace the comma with a period and add a pronoun to replace the subject. The meaning is clearer when the sentence is divided into two. The first sentence cites the Netherlands as another example and introduces one attribute of its land. The second sentence explains how it has used technology to address issues.
The subject is "it," which is singular, so the verb should be changed to "has" for subject-verb agreement.

incorrect sentence: Another example is Netherlands , whose most of his lands is a swamp under sea level , have used a good irrigation system to counter their problem and to make their land habitable .
correct sentence: Another example is Netherlands , where most of the land is swamp under sea level . It has used a good irrigation system to counter their problem and to make their land habitable .

corrections.explanation: The preposition "of" refers to attributes or ownership. Therefore, "need of," as in "he is in need of X," means "lacking in X." The preposition "for" can mean that something is for a certain cause or purpose. This better expresses the relationship between "need" and "habitable environment," so "of" should be changed to "for."

This correction isn't strictly necessary because the sentence is grammatically correct. However, the use of "increasing" could be better to emphasize "As the number of people grows" because "grow" and "increase" have similar meanings.

incorrect sentence: As the number of people grows , the need of habitable environment is unquestionably essential .
correct sentence: As the number of people grows , the need for habitable environment is unquestionably increasing .

corrections.explanation: English only capitalizes proper nouns and the first word of a sentence. Because "engineering" is a common noun and it appears mid-sentence, it should not be capitalized.

"Accommodation" means a place to stay. If a place is not habitable, it isn't usually considered accommodation, so the idea of "more habitable accommodation" is somewhat contradictory. "Environment" is a better choice because it refers to the surroundings overall or the natural world as a whole.

The indefinite article "a" refers to one thing, so the phrase "create a better material" to create one material, but this sentence is about material in general. In this case, it is common to say "create better material," in which "material" is an uncountable noun meaning matter from which something is made, or "create better materials," in which "materials" can refer to various building materials.

This correction isn't strictly necessary because the phrase is grammatically correct, but the edit makes it more concise and easy to understand. Following "designing stronger material" with the infinitive "to build" means to design stronger material in order to build something, or stronger material that can be used to build something. This conveys the nuance of "so it's possible" more concisely and clearly.

The verb "create," which means to bring something into existence, isn't normally used with buildings. There is no grammatical problem with "build," but the phrase "build buildings" sounds redundant, so it's common to say "construct."

The indefinite article "a" refers to one thing, so the phrase "a taller and safer building" means one such building. In reality, one building won't address overcrowding, so the plural "buildings" should be used and "a" should be deleted.

[1] This sentence lists two things that can be accomplished with stronger materials: (1) "to construct taller and safer buildings," and (2) "to create a better and efficient sanitation system." (1) and (2) are joined by a comma, but commas can only be used to link items in a list of three items or longer. Therefore, it requires the conjunction "and."

The subject of the sentence is "engineering designs" and it would be confusing to say "designs can help... by designing...". Designs do not design themselves, so it's better to simply say "designs can help... by changing...". Also, the indefinite article "a" refers to one thing, so "a way to change" means formulating one single method. It is assumed that engineers will design multiple ways, so it's better to say "finding ways to change" or, very simply, "changing."

"Inhabitable" means that the land can be lived on. The correct word is "uninhabitable," but alone, it can imply that the land cannot be made habitable. The phrase "otherwise uninhabitable" makes it clear that the conditions of the land can be changed, transforming it from uninhabitable to inhabitable.

incorrect sentence: In this era , Engineering designs can help to provide more habitable accommodation by designing a stronger material so it 's possible to create a taller and safer building , a better and efficient sanitation system to prevent disease , and also by designing a way to change the condition of the inhabitable environment .
correct sentence: In this era , engineering designs can help to provide more habitable environment by designing stronger material to build taller and safer buildings and a better and efficient sanitation system to prevent disease , and also by changing the condition of the otherwise uninhabitable environment .

corrections.explanation: "Technologically" is an adverb, so it modifies verbs, while "technological" is an adjective, so it modifies nouns. The word to be modified here is "determinists," which is a noun, so "technological" should be used instead.

incorrect sentence: Besides some technologically determinists that allow the development of biometric identification , this technology is also shaped by three social factors , namely , the desire of the society for safety , convenience and economy .
correct sentence: Besides some technological determinists that allow the development of biometric identification , this technology is also shaped by three social factors , namely , the desire of the society for safety , convenience and economy .

corrections.explanation: The verb "concern" means to make (someone) anxious or worried, as in "Global warming concerns me." In that sense, in this example, "safety" (subject) concerns (verb) "countries and companies" (object). However, when you change the object (countries and companies) to the subject, you should also change the structure using the phrase "(subject) + is concerned about." This means that the countries and companies feel anxious because of crucial problems like safety.

incorrect sentence: Safety is one of the crucial problems that many countries and companies concern .
correct sentence: Safety is one of the crucial problems that many countries and companies are concerned about .

corrections.explanation: The phrase "more and more" means increasing (in number), so it is always used with plural nouns. The singular "virus" should be changed to the plural "viruses."

"Hack" is a verb, and "hacking" is an action. The phrase "hacking can access personal computers" doesn't make sense because the action "hacking" needs someone to perform it. Therefore, it should be changed to "hackers," meaning people who engage in computer hacking.

"Data and documents" is a general concept that should be familiar to the reader, so it does not take the definite article "the" when used in a general sense. "The" is used with data only when drawing a distinction or a comparison between different pieces or types of data, and is not used in a general statement like this.

incorrect sentence: On one hand more and more virus and hack can access personal computers , so the secret data and documents may be stolen .
correct sentence: On one hand more and more viruses and hackers can access personal computers , so secret data and documents may be stolen .

corrections.explanation: "Administration" refers to the process of management or of running an organization. The phrase "strict administration" is not commonly used. "Rules" is a better choice because it means regulations or principles that govern procedure, and regulations can help to prevent information leaks.

"For" is used to indicate who is governed by rules. The preposition "to" refers to directionality or flow of movement toward something, while "for" can be used to indicate the person, thing, or purpose that something is for. "Rules" are made for the sake of governing the behavior of staff members, not toward the direction of staff members, so "for" is correct.

corrections.correct: staff members over the use of confidential information
corrections.explanation: The word "members" is not commonly used alone; it's much more common to say staff members, team members, etc. The phrase "over the use of confidential information" should be added for clarity. "Rules" alone is vague, so this phrase is added to indicate how the rules help to avoid information leaks, namely by governing the use of confidential information.

incorrect sentence: On the other hand , some important departments need strict administration to their members to avoid information leaks .
correct sentence: On the other hand , some important departments need strict rules for their staff members over the use of confidential information to avoid information leaks .

corrections.explanation: To say "The US DoD is one successful use of biometric identification" is confusing because it means that the department itself is a "use," which means the action of using something. "Example," on the other hand, means something that illustrates a general rule, and for a general rule to exist in the first place, it needs to have more than one example. Changing "use" to "example" conveys that the US DoD is one of several or many successful use cases of biometric identification. Also, if it is only one of many successful examples, then the writer's argument becomes even stronger.

incorrect sentence: The United States Department of Defense ( DoD ) { Common Access Card } [ HYPERLINK : http : //en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Access_Card ] is a successful use of biometric identification .
correct sentence: The United States Department of Defense ( DoD ) { Common Access Card } [ HYPERLINK : http : //en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Access_Card ] is a successful example of biometric identification .

corrections.explanation: This is a stylistic change because "involved" is grammatically correct. "Employ" means make use of, often toward a specific purpose. "Involved" means to have or include something in a process. This is vague, but "employ" describes specifically how biometric identification is involved in security, namely that it is used for a specific purpose.

I don't agree with this correction. "Security-sensitive" is not a commonly used phrase. I would change it to "high-security," or possibly leave it unchanged because "secure" is frequently used to mean needing higher security than average.

There is a difference in nuance between "humans" and "people." The word "human" is used more narrowly, mostly to refer to the human race as a whole, to distinguish human beings from other species, or to discuss human behavior in a scientific context. In most general, everyday uses, it's much more common to use "people."

incorrect sentence: As we can see , the biometric identification involved in important secure areas is designed to identify human with accuracy and reliability .
correct sentence: As we can see , the biometric identification employed in important security-sensitive areas is designed to identify people with accuracy and reliability .

corrections.explanation: The noun "identification" means the process of verifying someone's identity, but "for identification" does not contain the nuance of "in order to." Adding "purposes" makes this intent clear.

incorrect sentence: Besides safety , convenience is also desirable for identifications .
correct sentence: Besides safety , convenience is also desirable for identification purposes .

corrections.explanation: "Password" is a noun phrase that requires an article or pluralization. The definite article "the" would imply one specific password, and the indefinite article "a" would mean one single unspecified password, neither of which is the intended meaning, so the plural should be used.
I don't agree with this correction because a clause cannot begin with neither followed by a verb. It should be changed to "nor," which can begin a clause when followed by a verb.
"Equipment" is an uncountable noun, so it is already plural and cannot be pluralized with an "s."

Documents used to verify a person's identity are often called "identification," so the phrase "show one's identification" means to present an ID card or similar document. Also, the goal of the process of identification is not to verify a person's identifying documents but to verify their "identity," meaning who they are.

incorrect sentence: We do not want to spend time and effort to remember password , neither do we want to carry any cards or equipments to show our identification .
correct sentence: We do not want to spend time and effort to remember passwords , and neither do we want to carry any cards or equipment to show our identity .

corrections.explanation: "Equipment" is an uncountable noun, so it is already plural and cannot be pluralized with an "s."

The meaning of this phrase is unclear, so the editor may have chosen to delete it instead of guessing at a correction. If the meaning is "time-saving process" (rather than "progress"), I would suggest "...they are also looking for small equipment as well as ways to save time in the process of identification."

The preposition "of" refers to attributes or ownership, and "for" means for the sake or purpose of. "Equipment of identification" would mean that the equipment belongs to identification or that equipment is an aspect of identification, which does not make sense. "For" communicates that the equipment is used for the purpose of identification.

incorrect sentence: For government and other organizations , they are also looking for small size equipments and time-saving progress of identification .
correct sentence: For government and other organizations , they are also looking for small size equipment for identification .

corrections.explanation: I don't agree with this correction because a process usually takes the definite article "the" when used in a sentence. This serves to distinguish it from other processes. It is unusual for "process" to be preceded by a modifying noun phrase but have no article.
This is the wrong word. "Progress" means advancement or development, while "process" means a series of actions or steps taken toward a particular end.
"Equipment" is an uncountable noun, so it is already plural and cannot be pluralized with an "s."
"Equipment" is an uncountable noun, so it is already plural and cannot be pluralized with an "s."

incorrect sentence: Therefore nowadays the biometric identification progress is designed to be very quick , and the equipments can be easily set up or can be combined with other equipments .
correct sentence: Therefore nowadays biometric identification process is designed to be very quick , and the equipment can be easily set up or can be combined with other equipment .

corrections.explanation: The noun phrase fingerprint verification reader requires either an article or pluralization. The sentence begins with "We can," suggesting a single outcome out of multiple potential outcomes. It would be unusual to use the definite article "the" to refer to a potential outcome because "the" normally refers to specific things. The indefinite article suggests that this is one of multiple potential fingerprint verification readers, allowing for different mechanisms, brands, etc. This meaning makes sense. The plural suggests that the statement applies to multiple different types of fingerprint verification readers, which also makes sense. Either the indefinite article or the plural is acceptable.

In this scenario, the smartcard reader is built into the fingerprint verification reader. Because the two readers are part of the same device, their articles should match. The fingerprint verification reader is already marked with the indefinite article "a," meaning one of several potential options, so the smartcard reader should also use "a."

incorrect sentence: We can have fingerprint verification reader combined with built-in smartcard reader , and it only takes seconds to verify one 's identification .
correct sentence: We can have a fingerprint verification reader combined with a built-in smartcard reader , and it only takes seconds to verify one 's identification .

corrections.explanation: "Equipment" is an uncountable noun, so it is already plural and cannot be pluralized with an "s."
The subject is "equipment," which is uncountable and therefore treated as singular, so for subject-verb agreement, the verb should be "tends."
This is a spelling error. The correct spelling is "inexpensive."

incorrect sentence: Therefore , the equipments of biometric identification tend to be in-expensive .
correct sentence: Therefore , the equipment of biometric identification tends to be inexpensive .

corrections.explanation: When the relative pronoun "which" is used in a relative clause, it requires a second verb. "Retinal Technologies, Inc. (RTI)" is a relative clause, so if you use "which," it will require a second verb.

incorrect sentence: For instance , Retinal Technologies , Inc. ( RTI ) , which captures a retinal image at distances from the user 's eye with the means of just using a patented aspheric lens array .
correct sentence: For instance , Retinal Technologies , Inc. ( RTI ) , captures a retinal image at distances from the user 's eye with the means of just using a patented aspheric lens array .

corrections.explanation: The noun "benefit" requires either pluralization or an article. It refers to a result of something, so it is often plural because it is assumed that any action can cause multiple results. Unless it is known that there is only one singular benefit, usually it is used in the plural.

I don't agree with this correction because the phrase "the business," using the definite article "the," refers to one specific company or to its operational results. When talking about something that will be beneficial in general and not just to one specific firm, it's common to say "good for businesses," meaning good for all or most companies, or "good for business," an idiom meaning good for stimulating commerce or economic growth.

incorrect sentence: This technology is widely used in our society and it brings benefit to the government , the military , business and every individual .
correct sentence: This technology is widely used in our society and it brings benefits to the government , the military , the business and every individual .

corrections.explanation: There is a difference in nuance between "humans" and "people." The word "human" is used more narrowly, mostly to refer to the human race as a whole, to distinguish human beings from other species, or to discuss human behavior in a scientific context. In most general, everyday uses, it's much more common to use "people."

The verb "benefit" does not take the preposition "to" or any preposition. Also, the phrase "it benefits much those who shape it" is not commonly used. First, "much" is not often used with "benefit." It is more common to say "significantly," "tremendously," etc. Second, the word order "it benefits tremendously (someone)" is not commonly used. It is common to say "it benefits (someone) tremendously" or "it brings tremendous benefits to (someone)."

The past tense refers to past events, so the past tense "shaped" implies that the field of biometric identification is fixed and that nobody can have any impact on it anymore. This is not true, so it should be changed to "shape," the present tense form, to indicate that the field can still develop and change.

incorrect sentence: All in all , biometric identification achieves great development as human seek for better information protection , easier life style and greater economic profit , and it benefits much to those who shaped it .
correct sentence: All in all , biometric identification achieves great development as humans seek for better information protection , easier life style and greater economic profit , and it brings tremendous benefits to those who shape it .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had come," refers to a time in the past. The phrase "had come a long way since" means that "nuclear technology" was completed at some unspecified point between 1917 and today, but this sentence is talking about the present, not the past. The tense of the auxiliary verb "to have" is changed in to make past perfect into present perfect, which is used when past events are related to the present or continue to impact the present. Therefore, the present perfect "has come" is used to refer to a present condition and imply that it is affected by past events.

incorrect sentence: Nuclear technology had come a long way since Ernest Rutherford first split the atom in 1917 .
correct sentence: Nuclear technology has come a long way since Ernest Rutherford first split the atom in 1917 .

corrections.explanation: This is referring to past events, so it is inappropriate to use the present tense "can." The past tense "could" should be used instead.

The phrase "the subsequent realization... sparked" is in the past tense, so it refers entirely to past events, with no connection to today. To express that the effects are still continuing today, use the present perfect. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "sparked."

incorrect sentence: The subsequent realization that the additional neutrons produced from fission reaction can induce a nuclear chain reaction sparked off widespread interest in nuclear technology .
correct sentence: The subsequent realization that the additional neutrons produced from fission reaction could induce a nuclear chain reaction has sparked off widespread interest in nuclear technology .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had been," refers to a time in the past. The phrase "had been exploited for" means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. To relate this to present day, use the present perfect. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle passive voice "been exploited." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

"Has been through" comes from the phrasal verb "go through," meaning to undergo a difficult period or experience. It is mostly used for people or for countries, and it is unusual to use it with a technology, which cannot experience suffering. The relationship between nuclear power and wars/arms races is better expressed by "exploited for," which means to make full use of a resource and derive benefit from it.
A list of two things cannot be linked by a comma. The conjunction "and" is necessary.

The past perfect form, "had found," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. To relate this to present day, use the present perfect. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle passive voice "been exploited." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

incorrect sentence: Since then , nuclear technology had been through wars , arms races and had found many applications in the medical , industrial and energy fields .
correct sentence: Since then , nuclear technology has been exploited for wars and arms races and has found many applications in the medical , industrial and energy fields .

corrections.explanation: This sentence is referring to past events and requires the past tense. The past tense of the verb "spring" is "sprang," not "sprung."

The proper noun "America" doesn't take an article. The regions of North, South, and Central America can be referred to collectively as "the Americas," but the singular "America," referring to the United States, cannot.

incorrect sentence: The leakage of radioactive gas into the atmosphere prompted the many anti-nuclear demonstrations that sprung up across the America in the following months .
correct sentence: The leakage of radioactive gas into the atmosphere prompted the many anti-nuclear demonstrations that sprang up across America in the following months .

corrections.explanation: "Damaged" is a past tense verb form, so it cannot be the subject of a clause. It should be changed to the noun form "damage."

incorrect sentence: Although the reactor was eventually cleaned up and decontaminated , the damaged dealt to nuclear power was irreversible and caused its subsequent decline .
correct sentence: Although the reactor was eventually cleaned up and decontaminated , the damage dealt to nuclear power was irreversible and caused its subsequent decline .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had launched," refers to a time in the past. This phrase refers to something China had done as of a certain unspecified point in the past. But this 2030 plan is still ongoing today, so to relate this to present day, use the present perfect. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "launched." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

incorrect sentence: To partly offset this gigantic demand for energy , China had launched an ambitious program to produce 16 % of its electricity from nuclear power by 2030 .
correct sentence: To partly offset this gigantic demand for energy , China has launched an ambitious program to produce 16 % of its electricity from nuclear power by 2030 .

corrections.explanation: The subject is "this endeavor," which is singular, so for subject-verb agreement, the verb should be "has."

incorrect sentence: This endeavor to produce more nuclear power have stimulated the development of safer designs of nuclear reactors .
correct sentence: This endeavor to produce more nuclear power has stimulated the development of safer designs of nuclear reactors .

corrections.explanation: This sentence is referring to events or conditions that are still ongoing, so it is inappropriate to use the past tense, which indicates past events. It should be changed to the present tense "characterize."

incorrect sentence: Safety concerns characterized the basic concept of the Pebble Bed reactor with its passive safety design .
correct sentence: Safety concerns characterize the basic concept of the Pebble Bed reactor with its passive safety design .

corrections.explanation: This sentence joins two complete sentences with a comma and an adverb, which is not grammatically correct. Both "When machinery... levels" and "instead, the reactor... liquids" are complete sentences and they are related in meaning, so in order to join them, use either a conjunction or a semicolon.

incorrect sentence: When machinery failure occurs and reactor temperature increase to extremely high levels , the reactor does not undergo a meltdown or explode , instead temperature just stays at the high level until the heat can be dissipated or cooled by coolant liquids .
correct sentence: When machinery failure occurs and reactor temperature increase to extremely high levels , the reactor does not undergo a meltdown or explode ; instead , temperature just stays at the high level until the heat can be dissipated or cooled by coolant liquids .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had been," refers to a time in the past. The phrase "had always been" means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about present events, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "launched." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

incorrect sentence: In conclusion , nuclear technology development had always been driven by social factors .
correct sentence: In conclusion , nuclear technology development has always been driven by social factors .

corrections.explanation: I don't agree with this correction. The phrase "World War 2 had given it momentum in its initial research" is in the present perfect tense, which is used when the effects of past events are still relevant at present. However, nuclear technology is far past the stage of initial research where it required momentum from the war; it has been in practical use for a long time. Decades have passed since the end of the war that drove the research and since the initial research itself. Since neither one is ongoing or recent, I think the past tense "gave" is more appropriate than "has given" because the past tense refers to actions that were completed in the past.

incorrect sentence: World War 2 had given it momentum in its initial research , but it will be mankind 's need for a renewable and environmentally friendly energy source that will drive nuclear technology 's future developments .
correct sentence: World War 2 has given it momentum in its initial research , but it will be mankind 's need for a renewable and environmentally friendly energy source that will drive nuclear technology 's future developments .

corrections.explanation: The phrase "is trapping" is in the present continuous tense, referring to an action that is happening in the current moment. It's true that carbon dioxide is trapping heat now, but that is because it is trapping heat at all times. For events that occur constantly, regularly, or repeatedly, the present tense is used. It should be changed to "traps" to reflect that heat trapping is a constant characteristic of carbon dioxide, not a temporary effect at a specific moment.

incorrect sentence: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas which is trapping heat within the Earth .
correct sentence: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas which traps heat within the Earth .

corrections.correct: the process of designing such technologies
corrections.explanation: It's is not grammatically correct for a gerund to be followed by the verb "process." The preposition "of," which indicates an attribute, is used in "the process of designing" to reflect that designing constitutes the substance of the process. The phrase "such technologies" is added for specificity, as "the process of designing" is vague and could refer to designing anything. "Such" refers back to technologies that were referenced previously.

incorrect sentence: According to Khandani 's article on 'Engineering design process'1 , there are five steps to designing processes .
correct sentence: According to Khandani 's article on 'Engineering design process'1 , there are five steps to the process of designing such technologies .

corrections.explanation: Both "heat" and "trap" are nouns, so they create a noun phrase "heat trap," which refers to a type of plumbing valve. This sentence is about the heat trapped within the atmosphere, so it should use the adjective form "trapped," which can modify the noun "heat."

incorrect sentence: To reduce heat trap within the atmosphere , carbon dioxide level has to be reduced .
correct sentence: To reduce heat trapped within the atmosphere , carbon dioxide level has to be reduced .

corrections.explanation: "Equipment" is an uncountable noun, so it is already plural and cannot be pluralized with an "s."

incorrect sentence: Presently in the market , there are already technologies which can replace present day equipments and emit less carbon dioxide .
correct sentence: Presently in the market , there are already technologies which can replace present day equipment and emit less carbon dioxide .

corrections.explanation: The subject is "information," which is a collective noun referring to a variety of data. It also represents an abstract concept that is uncountable. Therefore, the verb should be "is" for subject-verb agreement.
The use of "articles" is unnecessarily wordy and confusing. Information is thought of as being disseminated by magazines and newspapers themselves, not by the articles they contain.

incorrect sentence: As the subject has been discussed for quite some time , relevant information are readily available on the internet and articles in magazines and newspapers .
correct sentence: As the subject has been discussed for quite some time , relevant information is readily available on the internet and in magazines and newspapers .

corrections.explanation: The verb "improve" means to make something better, but it doesn't necessarily mean to solve a problem. For weaknesses, it's better to use a verb like "overcome," which means to defeat or successfully deal with a difficulty.

"Strength" is singular, which means only one strength. Generally, things and people are assumed to have multiple strengths and multiple weaknesses, so unless it is clear that there is only one, the plural is generally used. Also, because it is preceded by the plural "weaknesses," it should be changed to the plural "strengths" for parallel structure.

incorrect sentence: These solutions may be generated by analyzing existing products to find out how the weaknesses can be improved while retaining the strength .
correct sentence: These solutions may be generated by analyzing existing products to find out how the weaknesses can be overcome while retaining the strengths .

corrections.error: in the economic and social aspects
corrections.correct: based on economic and social considerations
corrections.explanation: "Aspects" means a part or feature of something. The phrase "in the economic and social aspects" means to analyze only the parts of these solutions that are relevant to the economy or to society. To convey the idea of analyzing solutions from an economic and social perspective, it should be changed to "based on economic and social considerations."

incorrect sentence: They will then analyze the solutions in the economic and social aspects .
correct sentence: They will then analyze the solutions based on economic and social considerations .

corrections.explanation: This sentence joins two complete sentences with an adverb, which is not grammatically correct. Both "These products... market" and "hence... cost" are complete sentences, so in order to join them, use either a conjunction or a semicolon.

incorrect sentence: These products have to be sold in the market hence consumers must be convinced that these environmentally friendly products are as good as the present equipment in terms of performance and cost .
correct sentence: These products have to be sold in the market ; hence , consumers must be convinced that these environmentally friendly products are as good as the present equipment in terms of performance and cost .

corrections.explanation: The definite article "the" refers to a specific product, especially one that was mentioned earlier in the text. Because no such product was mentioned, it should be changed to the indefinite article "a," which refers to one single unspecified product out of multiple potential products.

incorrect sentence: Therefore careful analysis of the product has to be made before selecting a solution for testing and implementation .
correct sentence: Therefore careful analysis of a product has to be made before selecting a solution for testing and implementation .

corrections.explanation: The word "according" on its own is an adjective meaning harmonious or in agreement. In order to create a prepositional phrase meaning "as stated by," it requires the preposition "to." It should be changed from "according" to "according to."

incorrect sentence: According Khandani 's article , engineers can test the solution by prototyping or concurrent engineering .
correct sentence: According to Khandani 's article , engineers can test the solution by prototyping or concurrent engineering .

corrections.explanation: This sentence joins two complete sentences with an adverb, which is not grammatically correct. Both "These computer simulations... time" and "hence... time" are complete sentences, so in order to join them, use either a conjunction or a semicolon.
This statement is referring to a previous subject, "these computers," which is plural. Therefore, for subject-verb agreement, "they are" should be used instead.

incorrect sentence: These computer simulations take significantly shorter time hence it is a preferred choice as it means that the product can be sold in the market in a shorter period of time .
correct sentence: These computer simulations take significantly shorter time ; hence , they are a preferred choice as it means that the product can be sold in the market in a shorter period of time .

corrections.explanation: This is the wrong word. "Process" means a series of actions or steps taken toward a particular end, while "product" means an article or substance produced for sale. From prior context, the author is talking about technologies, so "product" is the more likely meaning.

incorrect sentence: Through the five designing steps , a process can be designed to meet the need to decrease carbon dioxide level .
correct sentence: Through the five designing steps , a product can be designed to meet the need to decrease carbon dioxide level .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had shown," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about present events, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "shown." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

The past perfect form, "had increased," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about a specified period, or the last decade, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "increased." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

The past perfect form, "had projected," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about present events, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "projected." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.
The verb "draw" on its own means to pull or drag, or to produce a picture. It needs "near" in order to convey the meaning of to approach or grow closer.

incorrect sentence: Research had shown that fuel consumption had increased twenty percent over the last decade , and had projected that the depletion of fuels is drawing .
correct sentence: Research has shown that fuel consumption has increased twenty percent over the last decade , and has projected that the depletion of fuels is drawing near .

corrections.explanation: The subject here is "burning," which is singular, so the verb should be "emits" for subject-verb agreement.

The phrase "pollute our fragile environment" modifies the phrase "various harmful gases" to clarify its meaning. Therefore, the relative noun "which" is needed to connect the two clauses. Otherwise it is a run-on sentence.

incorrect sentence: In addition , burning of fuels emit various harmful gases pollute our fragile environment .
correct sentence: In addition , burning of fuels emits various harmful gases which pollute our fragile environment .

corrections.explanation: This sentence uses the noun "cause," meaning a person or thing that gives rise to something. In such cases, "cause" takes the pronoun "of," which is used to indicate what caused an event. Therefore, the phrase "the main cause of global warming" means "the main thing that causes global warming."
The subject here is "global warming," which is singular, so the verb should be "gives" for subject-verb agreement.

incorrect sentence: These green house gases are the main cause to worldwide global warming which give rise to further catastrophes such as the rise in global temperature etc .
correct sentence: These green house gases are the main cause of worldwide global warming which gives rise to further catastrophes such as the rise in global temperature etc .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had already started," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about present events, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "started." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

incorrect sentence: Engineers around the world had already started on working on this problem .
correct sentence: Engineers around the world have already started on working on this problem .

corrections.explanation: "Themselves" is used to emphasize that the subject or object is one that has already been referenced. This sentence is saying that engineers have a set of steps that guide them, so both the subject "they" and the object "them(selves)" refer to the same thing: "engineers." In such cases, "themselves" is used to indicate that the pronoun is something that has already been mentioned.

The present tense "use" refers to an action that is currently or habitually performed. In this case, engineers have been performing the action since some time ago and still do so now. That is best expressed by the present perfect tense, "have used," which indicates that a past action is either still ongoing today or that its effects still endure.

corrections.error: which guide them in engineering a remedy
corrections.explanation: The idea of "which guide them" is already expressed in "To guide them," so it should be deleted to avoid repetition. There is nothing grammatically wrong with "in engineering a remedy," so this a stylistic edit, but the phrase adds little to the idea of "saving the earth." It's also unnecessarily wordy and potentially confusing, so deleting it achieves a clearer argument.

incorrect sentence: To guide them in this heavy responsibility of saving the earth , they use a set of simple steps which guide them in engineering a remedy , known as the Engineering Design Process .
correct sentence: To guide themselves in this heavy responsibility of saving the earth , they have used a set of simple steps , known as the Engineering Design Process .

corrections.explanation: This is the wrong word. "Mainly" means principally or for the most part, suggesting that there are other steps as well, but these are the five most important steps. "Namely" is a way of rephrasing a previously mentioned concept to be more exact, like "to be specific." It should be changed to "namely" to indicate that there are exactly five steps, which the author will then mention by name.

The pronoun is replacing the plural "ideas," so it is ungrammatical to use the singular pronoun "it." Also, the third and fourth steps both use the phrase "the ideas" rather than substituting a pronoun, so the reader will expect to hear "the ideas" in the fifth step as well. This creates parallel structure.

incorrect sentence: This process consists of five major steps , mainly defining the problem , researching on information pertaining to the problem , brainstorming of ideas , filtering of the ideas , and lastly implementing it .
correct sentence: This process consists of five major steps , namely defining the problem , researching on information pertaining to the problem , brainstorming of ideas , filtering of the ideas , and lastly implementing the ideas .

corrections.explanation: The preposition "of" indicates an attribute or a relationship of belonging, so "the search of alternative resources" suggests that alternative resources are conducting the search, which is not logical. The preposition "for" can mean the purpose for which something is done, or in order to help or cause something. The purpose of a search is to find an object, so "for" is used for the object.

incorrect sentence: Firstly , we can define this worldwide problem as the search of alternative resources to the existing near-depletion fuels .
correct sentence: Firstly , we can define this worldwide problem as the search for alternative resources to the existing near-depletion fuels .

corrections.explanation: I may agree with this correction depending on the intended meaning. The issue is about the plural "gases," which only ever means multiple gases, such as hydrogen gas, chlorine gas, etc. When referring to one gas, the word "gas" is not pluralized, regardless of how large the amount of gas may be. In other words, "gases" is countable and "gas" is sometimes countable, sometimes not. "Much" is used only to modify uncountable nouns, so it cannot be used with "gases." The phrase "a lot of" can be used with either countable or uncountable nouns, but with different meanings. "A lot of gas" means a large amount of gas, either one single gas or multiple gases. "A lot of gases" means many different gases, but does not indicate in what amount. If the author intends to say that fuels emit many different gases, the correction "a lot of gases" is valid. If the intended meaning is that fuel emits a large amount of gas or of gases, then it should be changed to "a large amount of gas" or "large amounts of gases," respectively.

"One" is used as a pronoun used to reference something that has already been mentioned. In this case, it means "alternatives," but "alternatives" is plural, so it cannot be replaced with the singular pronoun "one." Also, since "alternatives" is the subject, the current meaning of the sentence is "The alternatives we are looking for should be renewable alternatives," but alternatives to what? This is unclear, so it should be changed to something more specific, like "energy sources." (I've used the plural "energy sources" because, although the correction is valid overall, as it is incorrect to use the singular "energy source" with the plural "alternative.")

The verb "should" is missing. The sentence can be understood without it, but it is unusual and grammatically incorrect to use the verb for the first item of a two-item list but omit it for the second.

incorrect sentence: Since fuels are non renewable and emit so much harmful gases , the alternatives that we are looking for should be a renewable one and not emit harmful pollutants .
correct sentence: Since fuels are non renewable and emit a lot of harmful gases , the alternatives that we are looking for should be a renewable energy source and should not emit harmful pollutants .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had shown," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about present events, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "shown." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

incorrect sentence: Studies had shown that an average of 2 lbs ( pounds ) of fuel is needed to produce 1kilowatt of power .
correct sentence: Studies have shown that an average of 2 lbs ( pounds ) of fuel is needed to produce 1kilowatt of power .

corrections.explanation: I partially agree with this correction. "Realized" is not correct because it is the past tense, which refers to events that were completed in the past. However, the present tense "realize" is not correct either. The present tense refers to events that are currently ongoing or that occur regularly, but this realization is not currently in progress, nor is it occurring repeatedly. It occurred in the past but it still has an effect on our present. The present perfect tense is used for events that took place in the past but still affect the present, so the present perfect "have realized" is preferable.
The subject is "burning," which is singular, so the verb should be changed to "produces" to match.

The definite article "the" refers to a specific amount of gas or gases, especially one that was mentioned earlier in the text. Because no such amount was mentioned, it should be changed to the indefinite article "a," which refers to an unspecified or unknowable amount of gas or gases.

incorrect sentence: In addition , we realized that burning of fuels produce the large amount of greenhouse gases .
correct sentence: In addition , we realize that burning of fuels produces a large amount of greenhouse gases .

corrections.explanation: A comma is necessary when "which" precedes a nonrestrictive phrase, meaning a phrase that can be removed from the sentence without changing the meaning. The phrase "An example is water" is a full sentence whose meaning does not change if the clause that follows is removed, so the clause is nonrestrictive and a comma should be added.

incorrect sentence: An example is water which is a good renewable resource and is plentiful .
correct sentence: An example is water , which is a good renewable resource and is plentiful .

corrections.explanation: The phrase "same energy" is not used in the context of "energy" meaning usable power. It is used only for another meaning of "energy": aura, ambience, or mood. Also, the word "energy" on its own just means usable power, and it does not denote any amount at all. Without "amount of," the meaning of the sentence is partially lost.

incorrect sentence: This is because a large body of water is needed to harness the same energy produced by a small amount of fuel .
correct sentence: This is because a large body of water is needed to harness the same amount of energy produced by a small amount of fuel .

corrections.explanation: The definite article "the" refers to a specific group of engineers, especially one that was mentioned earlier in the text. Because no such group was mentioned, the article should be removed, in which case the plural "engineers" means most or all engineers, or any relevant engineers.

incorrect sentence: All the solutions will be thoroughly analysed by the engineers before coming to a conclusion .
correct sentence: All the solutions will be thoroughly analysed by engineers before coming to a conclusion .

corrections.explanation: The definite article "the" refers to a specific group of engineers, especially one that was mentioned earlier in the text. Because no such group was mentioned, the article should be removed, in which case the plural "engineers" means most or all engineers, or any relevant engineers.

incorrect sentence: Lastly , the engineers will put their solution to test and ensure that the solution is able to solve the problem .
correct sentence: Lastly , engineers will put their solution to test and ensure that the solution is able to solve the problem .

corrections.explanation: The phrase "make use of" is commonly used and it always requires the preposition "of." Also, this sentence is referring to events or conditions that are still ongoing, so it is inappropriate to use the past tense, which indicates past events. It should be changed to the present tense "make use of."

incorrect sentence: As such , engineers made use wind turbines and water hydraulic generators to harness the wind and water energy respectively .
correct sentence: As such , engineers make use of wind turbines and water hydraulic generators to harness the wind and water energy respectively .

corrections.correct: Harnessing the wind and water energy
corrections.explanation: I partially agree with this correction. The pronoun "It" does lack clarity, but rather than repeating the subject of the previous sentence, I would change it to "This," which refers back to the subject of the previous sentence. It's more common to substitute a pronoun for the subject unless the last mention of the subject is far away. In this case, it was last mentioned at the end of the previous sentence, so the reader still remembers it at the start of this sentence, and it is unusual to repeat a long phrase twice in such quick succession.

The conjunction "but" is used to link two contradictory or seemingly contradictory ideas. When these ideas are independent clauses, meaning that they each form a full sentence on their own, then "but" always requires a comma. Both "Harnessing... option" and "both sources... resources" have a subject and a verb, making them both full sentences. Therefore, they can be connected with a comma and the conjunction "but."

First, remove the dash, which defines "the depleting resource" as "fuel." Then, change to the noun phrase "fuel resources," meaning the stock or supply of fuel, because it more clearly communicates that the finite amount of fuel in existence is diminishing. In the phrase "slow down the depleting fuel resources," the object of the verb "to slow down" is "fuel." This means fuel is being slowed down fuel, so the phrase should be modified to convey that what's being slowed down is the depletion of fuel. To do this, change "depleting" to "depletion of."

incorrect sentence: It may not be the best option but both sources are renewable and are able to be used to slow down the depleting resource - fuel .
correct sentence: Harnessing the wind and water energy may not be the best option , but both sources are renewable and are able to be used to slow down the depletion of fuel resources .

corrections.explanation: The past perfect form, "had shown," refers to a time in the past. This phrase means that the action was completed by a certain unspecified point in the past. But this statement is about present events, so use the present perfect to relate it to present day. This requires the auxiliary verb "have" or "has" plus the past participle "shown." This phrase conveys that the effects of this past action are still continuing or relevant today.

The conjunction "and" is used to link two ideas. When these ideas are independent clauses, meaning that they each form a full sentence on their own, then "and" requires a comma. Both "This has... solving problems" and "it ensures... harmful (gases)" are full sentences, so they can be connected with a comma and the conjunction "but."

The conjunction "that" serves to connect the phrase "the engineers... harmful (gases)" to the verb "ensures," so there is no need to repeat the verb. If choosing to repeat the verb for stylistic reasons, it should be changed from "ensure" to "ensures" so that it agrees with the subject "it," which is singular.

The verb "target" means to take aim at, particularly with an attack or a message, while "address" means to deal with a problem and attempt to solve it. "Target" does not contain the nuance of solving, so it is not commonly used with "problems," and "address" is the better choice.
"Fuels" has not been mentioned in this sentence, so it is unclear what "the depletion" is referencing.

The phrase "harmful fuel" means that fuel itself is harmful, which is not true. The harm comes from gases, which are emitted during the extraction and burning of fuels. To accurately reflect what "the main problem" is, it should be changed to "the emission of harmful gases."

incorrect sentence: This had shown that the engineering design process is essential in solving problems and it ensures that the problem is thoroughly looked into and ensure that the engineers are generating ideas that target the main problem , the depletion and harmful fuel .
correct sentence: This has shown that the engineering design process is essential in solving problems , and it ensures that the problem is thoroughly looked into and that the engineers are generating ideas that address the main problem , the depletion of fuels and the emission of harmful gages .

corrections.explanation: This is a stylistic correction, not a grammatical one. The sentence is more clear with the addition of "adoption of" because the phrase "Since the reform and open policy" alone implies that the policy was an event that occurred naturally or without human action. Since policies are a human invention, it is more common to say "Since the adoption of the..."

When used as a noun, a decade always uses the definite article "the." This is because the definite article is used to refer to a particular unit or period of time. The decade of the 1970s only occurred once, so it is a specific, definite thing, and the article should be used.

The noun phrase "on its way to" means being in progress or in a state of development toward something. It is a state of being, not an action, and the verb phrase "to speed up" is basically only used with actions or vehicles. Therefore, "process" is a better word choice because it means a series of actions that lead to a particular result.

Firstly, "on its way to" followed by the verb "flourish" is not grammatically correct. "Flourish" should be changed to the gerund "flourishing" when used in the phrase "in the process of," because this phrase requires a noun and gerunds can act as a noun. Secondly, the word "flourish" is not commonly used in this context, so it should be changed to "development."

incorrect sentence: Since the reform and open policy in 1970 's , China has been eagerly speeding up on its way to industrialization and flourish .
correct sentence: Since the adoption of the reform and open policy in the 1970 's , China has been eagerly speeding up its process of industrialization and development .

corrections.explanation: This correction does not fix the problem. The phrase "stand out becoming" is not correct in English. To convey the meaning of "prominent," it should say something like "two major difficulties that have become prominent are the education system and the perception of innovation." This means that China faces multiple major difficulties, and that two in particular are now very noticeable: the education system and the perception of innovation. Also, this correction adds the definite article "the" to both of the difficulties. "The" is used to refer to one specific thing, so it means "China's" education system" and "China's perception of innovation."

incorrect sentence: Among them , education system and perception of innovation stand out becoming two major difficulties .
correct sentence: Among them , education system and perception of innovation are two major difficulties .

corrections.explanation: The adverb "deeply" means complete, extreme, or strongly felt. It is not commonly used with "throttling." It's more common to use "greatly," which has a similar meaning: to a great extent or degree.

incorrect sentence: However , China 's examination-oriented education system deeply throttles students ' creativity .
correct sentence: However , China 's examination-oriented education system greatly throttles students ' creativity .

corrections.explanation: "The whole society" is an idiom meaning all parts of society, or basically every member of society. "The whole..." means complete or full, not lacking or leaving out any part. This idiom is always used with the article "the."

1) I partially agree with this question. The phrase "concentrating on how" needs to be removed, but the meaning still is not conveyed strongly enough. First, the verb "pressure" is stronger than "push." Second, the sentence should use the passive voice, in which the subject undergoes the action of the verb. This makes "students" the subject, the passive particle "are pressured" is the verb. The sentence "Students are pressured to achieve outstanding marks in examinations not only by parents and teachers but also by the whole society" shifts the focus to students and emphasizes the intensity of the pressure.

2) Not only parents and teachers but all of society is pressuring students to achieve outstanding marks in examination.
OR　
Not only parents and teachers, but society as a whole, is pressuring students to achieve outstanding marks in examination.

Either way, the main idea is that society is pushing students to get good marks. This idea remains intact even if the confusing phrase "concentrating on how" is removed, so it's better to remove it.

incorrect sentence: Not only parents and teachers but also whole society pushes students concentrating on how to get outstanding marks in examinations .
correct sentence: Not only parents and teachers but also the whole society pushes students to get outstanding marks in examinations .

corrections.error: for the simple reason that these can help them
corrections.explanation: This is a stylistic correction, not a grammatical one. "For the simple reason that these can help them" is grammatically correct, but "simply to" expresses the same idea much more concisely and clearly, and with less possibility for confusion.

incorrect sentence: Students spend most of their time reciting details in text books and doing tedious exercises again and again for the simple reason that these can help them get familiar with examinations .
correct sentence: Students spend most of their time reciting details in text books and doing tedious exercises again and again simply to get familiar with examinations .

corrections.explanation: The phrase "creative thinking" refers to the process of thinking creatively. In this sentence, "creative thinking" is the object of the verb "develop," but what the students are developing is not the process of thinking creatively, but the ability to think creatively. Also, creative thinking is considered to require a variety of different abilities, such as analytical skills, innovation, brainstorming, the empathy to see things from other peoples' perspectives, etc. Therefore, "abilities" is always plural in the phrase "creative thinking abilities."

"Stereotype" requires an article, and it should be changed to "a stereotype," because the indefinite article "a" implies one of several or many potential stereotypes whereas the definite article "the" implies one specific stereotype, usually one mentioned previously in the text. "The" is appropriate here because no stereotype was mentioned previously in the text. The correction, however, removes "stereotype" entirely. The sentence ends with the word "become," which requires an object. This is ungrammatical and also vague because it does not specify what the students are becoming.

incorrect sentence: As a result , students have no chance to develop their creative thinking and gradually become stereotype .
correct sentence: As a result , students have no chance to develop their creative thinking abilities and gradually become .

corrections.explanation: The phrase "Many years ago" means that this statement is referring to past events, so it is inappropriate to use the present tense "is." It should be "was" instead.

incorrect sentence: Many years ago , the situation is different .
correct sentence: Many years ago , the situation was different .

corrections.explanation: The verb "major" is in the present tense, but it is preceded by the past tense verb "entered," which refers to past events. It should be changed to the gerund "majoring," which expresses a condition. Also, the bare infinitive present tense can only begin a clause when used as a command.

incorrect sentence: In 1931 , Qian Weichang entered Tsing Hua University , major in history with 0 marks in mathematics and physics .
correct sentence: In 1931 , Qian Weichang entered Tsing Hua University , majoring in history with 0 marks in mathematics and physics .

corrections.explanation: The possessive "one year's study" is used to mean "study of one year." The pronoun "of" can indicate what an amount or number refers to. It also refers to a relationship of ownership. The year was spent studying, so the year belonged to study, so it is one year of study.
